title: 110_hr913
content: The Act titled "Hurricane and Tornado Mitigation Investment Act of 2007" introduces a nonrefundable personal credit for hurricane and tornado mitigation property under section 25E of the Internal Revenue Code of 1986. The Act "Hurricane and Tornado Mitigation Investment Act of 2007" introduces a nonrefundable personal credit for qualified hurricane and tornado mitigation property expenditures. The credit allows 25% of the expenditures, up to a maximum of $5,000 per taxable year, for specific property improvements. The Act "Hurricane and Tornado Mitigation Investment Act of 2007" offers a nonrefundable personal credit for qualified hurricane and tornado mitigation property expenditures. This credit applies to specific property improvements such as improving roof durability, bracing gable-end walls, reinforcing roof-to-wall connections, protecting openings from windborne debris, and safeguarding exterior doors and garages in qualified dwelling units located in certain states. A qualified dwelling unit is assessed at a value less than $1,000,000 in the locality where it is situated. The Act "Hurricane and Tornado Mitigation Investment Act of 2007" provides a nonrefundable personal credit for qualified hurricane and tornado mitigation property expenditures. The credit applies to specific property improvements in certain states, with onsite preparation, assembly, or installation completed by a State-certified inspector. Labor costs are also eligible for the credit. The Act "Hurricane and Tornado Mitigation Investment Act of 2007" allows for labor and inspection costs related to onsite preparation, assembly, or installation of qualified property to be considered in determining eligible expenditures for the taxpayer. The Act "Hurricane and Tornado Mitigation Investment Act of 2007" introduces a new section for a business-related credit for hurricane and tornado mitigation, effective for taxable years starting after December 31, 2007. The Hurricane and Tornado Mitigation Credit allows for a 25% credit on qualified property expenditures, with a maximum credit of $5,000 per year. Qualified expenditures include improving roof deck attachment, creating a secondary water barrier, and enhancing roof covering durability. The Hurricane and Tornado Mitigation Credit allows for a 25% credit on qualified property expenditures, including improving roof deck attachment, reinforcing gable-end walls, and protecting openings from windborne debris. Qualified business must be assessed at less than $5,000,000 and located in a qualified State. The term 'qualified State' includes specific states. Expenditures for qualified hurricane and tornado mitigation property must be completed by a State-certified inspector. Labor costs are considered for these expenditures. Expenditures for labor and inspection costs related to the preparation, assembly, or installation of qualified hurricane and tornado mitigation property are considered in determining the taxpayer's qualified expenditures for the taxable year. The taxpayer's qualified expenditures for the taxable year include labor and inspection costs for qualified hurricane and tornado mitigation property. Additionally, a new paragraph (32) regarding the hurricane and tornado mitigation credit is added to the Code. The amendments made by this section regarding the hurricane and tornado mitigation credit apply to taxable years beginning after December 31, 2007.
